Here are two weapons, both chambered for the 9mm Makarov round, and both weapons are in very good condition.

The CZ 82 features a double stack magazine and a polygonal barrel.  This gun fire very nicely and comes with 2-12 round magazines.

The P83 features and de-cocking lever and 2 single stack, 8 round magazines, 

This package will include: a black holster that will fit either weapon, 1 magazine holder (meant for the CZ82), 200 rounds of boxer primed ammunition, 200 rounds of empty reloadable cartridges, Lee reloading dies and the cleaning rod that came with the CZ.

title: For Sale:  Becker BK7 Combat / Utility Knife
postcontent:
The BK&T COMBAT/UTILITY 7 has been designed specifically for soldiers and adventurers requiring a sturdy but lightweight combat knife that can stand up to hard use. The inspiration for the COMBAT/UTILITY 7 is the timeless MK-2 FIGHTING KNIFE that CAMILLUS CUTLERY helped develop during the second world war.

The COMBAT/UTILITY 7 has a 7" 0170-6C carbon tool steel blade that is tough enough for any field task and is flat ground to the BECKER shaving sharp edge. The steel is coated with a protective matte black epoxy/powdercoat finish for stealthy protection against elements.

The brawny .188" thick clip point blade is the perfect complement for a knife that may be used for piercing as well as prying. An integral inline hammering pommel has been engineered into the blade tang and is useful for a variety of military and survival uses.

The sheath Nylon and has a Kydex insert to shield the blade. The sheath has a gusseted front accessory pouch that can house survival gear, sharpeners, multitool, etc. The belt loop is large enough to accommodate a GI pistol belt, and also features ALICE clip slots for attachment to LBE gear. The sheath has a "pull the dot" snap loop, and set of eyelets for lashing the knife into the sheath, thus providing dual retention to be "Jump Safe" for airborne operations.

Specifications 
Exclusive high carbon steel (0170-6C) 
58-59 RC blade hardness 
Desert tan epoxy coating 
Becker trademark GV6H ergonomic handles 
Blade Length: 7 in. 
Blade Shape: Clip point 
Blade Steel: High carbon steel (0170-6C) 
Grind: High, flat saber grind 
Knife Type: Fixed Blade 
Manufactured: Made in USA 
Weight: 12.9 oz.

title: For Sale:  AK-47 Kit

If you have the tools this is a relatively easy build to finish, my friend who had the tools I was using got pissed and we argued so now I have no tools to finish this build. title: For Sale:  Glock 35 Practical Tactical with Upgrades and Storm Lake 9mm Conversion Barrel and Extras
postcontent:
*SOLD*
This post is for a highly customized gen 3 Glock 35 .40 cal practical tactical that is better than new in the hard box with other extras.  It has a lot of upgrades.  These include a Ghost 3.5# trigger connector,  Jager steel recoil guide rod, Jager reduced power recoil spring(for reliably cycling decreased power/sub-sonic ammo), extended magazine release, Wolff competition spring kit, maritime spring cups and polished internals.  It also comes with all original stock parts as well.  It is durcoated in "urban rattler camo" and does come with the almost new match grade Storm Lake 9mm conversion barrel shown,  (6 mags)three high-cap .40 cal mags and one 10 rd, two 9mm mags(one is an aftermarket 32rd 9mm mag with +2 extension(Not shown) and a black and tan right handed suede leather holster, as well as a slick black leather slider holster.  The round count is fairly low at around 700 rds. between the two barrels, with the majority fired through the stock .40 barrel. The frame also has a new set of Rock Solid Outfitters gator grips installed. (Not the wrap around shown) Neither sweat, mud, crap nor blood will cause this pistol to slip with these grips installed.
I am asking $700 obo cash for the entire package deal FTF in/around Knoxville and the only trade I know I would be interested in at this time is a good condition Keltec PF-9 or maybe a P-32.  I would give somewhere between $200-300 trade, depending on pistol, condition and accessories but would need the rest in cash.
I live inside the city limits but if you have a place to shoot, I will happily let you test fire a few rounds of your ammo so you can see/feel the difference between this Glock and a stock Glock. 
This is how definitely one way to rock a Glock !
Please check out the pics and let me know if you have any questions or need a specific picture or have any questions.  I plan to add some new pics soon.  The ones shown now were mostly taken to show the Burris Fastfire II that has already been sold and is not included with this pistol.
Thanks and let me know if you would like to check it out.
Dave

title: For Sale:  Mauser C-96 Broom Handle
postcontent:
*** Mauser C-96 ** Broom Handle ***

Location: Canton

Willing to Ship: Yes

Item is for: Sale Only

Sale Price: $1499

Caliber: 7.63x25

[b]Item Description:[/b] I am selling an excellent example of a Mauser C-96. This one was manufactured in 1914. The finish is in great shape and has not been reblued. 

History
The Mauser C96 (Construktion 96)[3] is a semi-automatic pistol that was originally produced by German arms manufacturer Mauser from 1896 to 1937.[4] Unlicensed copies of the gun were also manufactured in Spain and China in the first half of the 20th century.[4][5]

The distinctive characteristics of the C96 are the integral box magazine in front of the trigger, the long barrel, the wooden shoulder stock which can double as a holster or carrying case and a grip shaped like the handle of a broom. The grip earned the gun the nickname "Broomhandle" in the English-speaking world and in China the C96 was nicknamed the "box cannon" (Chinese: ???; pinyin: hézipào) because of its square-shaped internal magazine and the fact it could be holstered in its wooden box-like detachable stock.[6] It was used by the Latvian anarchist Peter Piaktow in 1911 and was therefore known as a 'Peter the Painter' gun by the IRA.[7]

The Mauser C96, with its shoulder stock, long barrel and high-velocity cartridge had superior range and better penetration than most other pistols; the 7.63×25mm Mauser cartridge was the highest velocity commercially manufactured pistol cartridge until the advent of the .357 Magnum cartridge in 1935.[8]

Approximately 1 million C96 pistols were manufactured by Mauser,[9] with the number produced in Spain and China being large but unknown due to the loss, non-existence or poor upkeep of production records from those countries.

Within a year of its introduction, the C96 had been sold to governments and commercially for resale to civilians and individual military officers.

The Mauser C96 pistol was also extremely popular with British officers at the time and purchased privately by many of them; numbers were supplied to Westley Richards in the UK for this purpose, although its popularity with the British military had waned by the onset of World War I.[10]

As a military sidearm, the pistols saw service in various colonial wars, as well as World War I, The Estonian War of Independence, the Spanish Civil War, the Chinese Civil War and World War II. The C96 also became a staple of Bolshevik Commissars and various warlords and gang leaders in the Russian Civil War.

Indian Revolutionary Ram Prasad Bismil and his partymen used these Mauser Pistols in the historical Kakori train robbery on 9 August 1925. His lieutenant Ashfaqullah Khan gave his Mauser to Manmath Nath Gupta and engaged himself to break open the cash chest. Incidentally, Manmath Nath Gupta tried to fire the newly seen weapon and a passenger was killed in the action.

Winston Churchill was fond of the Mauser C96 and used one at the Battle of Omdurman and during the Second Boer War; similarly, Lawrence of Arabia carried a Mauser C96 for a period during his time in the Middle East.[4][11] Chinese Communist general Zhu De carried a Mauser C96 during his Nanchang Uprising and later conflicts; his gun (with his name printed on it) can be viewed in the Beijing war museum.

Imported and domestic copies of the C96 were used extensively by the Chinese in the Second Sino-Japanese War and the Chinese Civil War, as well as by the Spanish during the Spanish Civil War and the Germans in World War II.[5][12]

Besides the standard 7.63×25mm chambering, C96 pistols were also commonly chambered for 9×19mm Parabellum with a small number also being produced in 9 mm Mauser Export. There was also a Chinese-manufactured model chambered for .45 ACP.[4] Despite the pistol's worldwide popularity and fame, the only nation to use the C96 as the primary service pistol of its military and police was China. The Broomhandle Mauser has become a popular collector's gun.[4]

The C96 frequently appears as a "foreign" or "exotic" pistol in a number of films and TV shows, owing to its distinctive and instantly recognisable shape,[4] and for the same reasons and in the same tradition, a C96 was modified to form Han Solo's prop blaster pistol for the Star Wars film

[b]Pictures:[/b]

I build custom Longbows but no matter how hard I try I cannot hit quail on the fly.  I want a 16ga possibly a 20ga SxS shotgun. Preferably a Lefever nitro or Fox B. LC Smith will work. Chokes must be Ic & Mod or Skeet. No cut barrels, prefer 2 3/4 chambers but like lightweight classics. www.7lakeslongbow.com 
Mike Ballenger

title: For Sale/Trade:  3 Tactical Remington Shotguns
location: Rowan County, North Carolina, United States
postcontent:
Up for sale or trade are three tactical Remington Shotguns. 

1. Remington 870 Tactical Magnum- 

This amazing shotgun was a limited run for the 2005 Shot Show. They are pretty difficult to find, especially at a fair price. It comes from the factory duracoated in OD green. The magazine tube capacity is 7+1 which is also a factory modification. This shotgun also has the pistol grip. There are a few light knicks and dings but nothing serious. The OD is actual OD green. I know it is difficult to see in the photos, but I assure you, it is OD green. I am asking $525 or best offer. 


2. Remington 870 Wingmaster- 

This 870 has been heavily upgraded and is in great condition. The finish has a bright color and really looks great with the stainless accents. The stock is a tapco intrafuse, molded pistol grip, a railed pump for mounting lights, etc.. It also comes with a forward grip mounted to the pump. When I purchased this shotgun, I changed the barrel to a mossberg brand 18.5 inch door breacher barrel. It also has a side shell holder. The magazine capacity is 4+1, so 8 shells are ready for your disposal. I am asking $400 or best offer.

3. Remington 870- 

This gun has been upgraded with a choate stock which also includes a 5 shell holder incorporated into the stock. The barrel is 18.5 inches long and is also a mossberg door breacher barrel which is a direct replacement for 870's. This gun is in good condition. I am asking $375 or best offer. 

I went on a tactical shotgun kick for quite a while but it is now time for me to move on. I will consider negotiating with a cash buyer that wants to purchase all three. If you have any questions, please feel free to email me. I am interested in some trades but cash is king, so the trade must be worth my while.

title: For Sale:  HK P7 HKP7 Arlington Import Commercial Import Not Police Surplus
postcontent:
Hello,

This is not a police trade in that you might find more frequently.  This is a commercial imported P7 that was brought into Arlington back in the early 80s.  This is a collector piece, but it also happens to be the best shooting P7 out of 6 different P7s that I have shot.

Without a doubt, this weapon will outshoot any other weapon its size and it is capable of out-grouping your 1911.  In spite of that accuracy, this is the fastest weapon made to draw, cock, and fire.  It's also the only handgun that I've ever felt comfortable in carrying with one in the chamber.

I could ramble on for a few hours about the accolades of the P7, and this is one of the most desirable of the P7 PSP.

Notice that this one has the wide and flush magazine release.  The earlier Arlington imports had a protruding mag release which is not as desirable as the later flush mag release.  The early Arlingtons with the protruding mag release have had some cracking issues with the welds in the slide.  The later P7M8 models have issues with cosmetics and also with broken firing pin bushings...it's what happens when you try to re-engineer a masterpiece.

This Arlington P7 PSP is the sweet spot of all the years this gun was made....absolutely the best of the best.

Yes, this weapon has been carried and it has been shot.  But it is in perfect working order and you won't believe what it can do.

Please note, that this deal is for the P7 and magazine only....other toys pictured are not included :)

Thanks for looking.
